lines.text: Have you thought about it? About what we said after Stalin dies?
Like what?
His crimes?
What crimes?
Millions...

Nikita, you are too emotional. You talk too much. Who are we to judge Stalin. Before him we were a weak, backward country, Now look at us. We control half of Europe... the whole of China... We have the atomic bomb... We command respect. Without Stalin, it would have take twenty years longer.
I don't be;ieve it. Without the purges, the arrests, the killings... without Stalin, we could have been a great country.
Our history required Stalin.
We were promised our lives.
Comrade Stalin has revoked his promise.
You think I don't know? Stalin knows. I know what you say, what you do, who you screw. I know everything about you.

[Referring to Stalin, who's on his deathbed]
Hemorrhage on his brain... He can't breathe.

[vindictively]
Let him die - murdering bastard.

[the dying Stalin chuckles and it appears he's regaining consciousness, so Beria panics and begins kissing Stalin's hand]
Forgive me... forgive me... forgive me...
[Stalin goes back into his coma, and Beria feels safe, so he spits on the floor in contempt]
Hitler will go the way of Napoleon... to defeat, to despair, and to his death.

[to Stalin about Sergei]
He died of silence. He didn't die of cancer.

[Referring to her pet fox]
Why won't he come to me?
A fox has a mind of his own... even a red fox.

[about Stalin]
The mass conspirator accuses everyone else of conspiracy.

[as narrator]
Nadia thought Stalin was going to change Russia...
[ironically]
She was right.
No brutality should be allowed although no revolution is possible without terror.

[Referring to an ill Lenin]
May I talk to him?
Since when do you ask permission?
